page.title: 08THE FAIRS OF ABINGDON
page.content: The first of the charters to be connected with Abingdon was granted by Edward 1 in l290. It was giving the King's permission for a seven day fair, beginning on the 9th June, to be held in honour of St. Edmund. The money raised from this fair to be used for the upkeep of the chapel of St. Edmund,which was possibly in West St. Helens Street. By 1609 Abingdon was allowed to hold seven fairs, each for a different purpose. The fair was moved to Ock Street mid-way through the l8th century, by which time it was held on Michaelmas, and was a hiring fair,where men looked for work. A week later the runaway fair is held, when labourers could be re-hired, who had run away from their new employer after the Michaelmas Fair. These two fairs are still held today.(see page 9) Written by Marie Thomas aged 10 years.
